review.title: Probabilistic Argumentation with Epistemic Extensions and Incomplete Information
review.abstract: Abstract argumentation offers an appealing way of representing and evaluating arguments and counterarguments. This approach can be enhanced by a probability assignment to each argument. There are various interpretations that can be ascribed to this assignment. In this paper, we regard the assignment as denoting the belief that an agent has that an argument is justifiable, i.e., that both the premises of the argument and the derivation of the claim of the argument from its premises are valid. This leads to the notion of an epistemic extension which is the subset of the arguments in the graph that are believed to some degree (which we defined as the arguments that have a probability assignment greater than 0.5). We consider various constraints on the probability assignment. Some constraints correspond to standard notions of extensions, such as grounded or stable extensions, and some constraints give us new kinds of extensions.

sections.heading: 6 Application: Partial probability functions
sections.text: Mapping a probability value to an argument is useful for a variety of purposes, such as representing the belief that the premises of the argument are valid, or believing that the claim is valid because the premises are valid, or believing that both the premises and the claim are valid, or believing that the argument should appear in the argumentation diagram, etc. This means that it can be difficult for a user to assign a value to each argument. If this is the case, then it would be desirable to have techniques to handle this incomplete information. Ideally, we would identify an appropriate mapping for all arguments based on the mapping to the remaining arguments.

sections.heading: 7 Discussion
sections.text: In this paper, we have examined the use of a probability function to represent the belief in an argument. We use this to identify an epistemic label and thus an epistemic extension. The notion of an epistemic extension is very general, since there are no limitations on the probability function in general. However, we have taken into account various limitations of the probability function, which lead to two views on the use of probability functions, namely the standard view and the non-standard view. Many of the limitations of the probability function that we have examined take into account aspects of the structure of the argument graph. We have applied our classification of the properties of probabilistic reasoning to the problem of supplementing partial probability assignments. An initial investigation leads us to believe that maximizing entropy within the probability functions of a particular type provides adequate results for this problem. In future work, we will examine this problem in more depth.
